children.name: to prevent sb from doing sth
prevent b1
children.definition: prevent/prɪˈvent/  to make it impossible for someone to do something that they want to do:ngăn chặn, phòng tránh
examples: prevent somebody from doing something
▪ a leg injury may prevent shearer from playing in tomorrow’s game.
▪ there were reports that some people had been prevented from voting in the election.

children.name: stop b1
children.definition: stop/stɒpǁstɑːp/  to stop someone from doing something that they want to do, especially by controlling them in an unreasonable way: ngừng lại, ngăn cản
examples: ▪ i’ve made up my mind to leave home, and you can’t stop me.
stop somebody (from) doing something
▪ my parents tried to stop me seeing anne.
▪ the government has taken legal action to stop the bbc from broadcasting a documentary about the secret service.

children.name: keep b1
children.definition: keep sb from doing sth to prevent sb from doing sth, especially sth that might be harmful or upsetting: ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
examples: ▪ staying busy kept her from thinking about her illness.
▪ it was all i could do to keep myself from hitting him.

children.name: restrain c1
children.definition: restrain/rɪˈstreɪn/  to prevent someone from doing something harmful or stupid, either by physically stopping them or by persuading them not to do it:kiềm chế, ngăn lại
examples: ▪ roger stepped forward and martin put out his arm to restrain him.
restrain yourself: tự kiềm chế
▪ she wanted to ask him all about his private life, but wisely restrained herself.
restrain somebody from doing something: ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
▪ his arm was hurting him and he had to be restrained from doing too much.

children.name: hold back c1
children.definition: hold back/ˌhəʊld ˈbæk/  to prevent someone or something from moving forward or making progress:ngăn lại, giữ lại
examples: hold back somebody/something: ngăn, giữ lại ai/cái gì
▪ the police had already erected crash barriers to hold back the advancing crowds.
▪ the poor economic situation has held back investment in new technology.
hold somebody/something back: ngăn/giữ ai/cái gì lại
▪ bill leapt to his feet to go after the girl, but the others held him back.
▪ she always felt that being a woman had held her back in her career.

children.name: get in the way of u
children.definition: get in the way of/ˌget ɪn ðə ˈweɪ ɒv/  to make someone too busy to do something else, especially something they should do:cản đường
examples: ▪ don’t let your social life get in the way of your education.

children.name: discourage b2
children.definition: discourage/dɪsˈkʌrɪdʒǁ-ˈkɜːr-/  to make it less likely that someone will do something, for example by showing them that it may have a bad or unwelcome result:can ngăn
examples: ▪ higher taxes are likely to discourage investment.
▪ it is a well known fact that a negative working environment discourages creativity.
discourage somebody from doing something: can ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
▪ higher cigarette prices do not seem to discourage people from smoking.

children.name: a problem that prevents you from achieving sth
obstacle c1
children.definition: obstacle/ˈɒbstəkəlǁˈɑːb-/  a problem that makes it difficult but not impossible for you to achieve what you want to achieve:cản trở
examples: the lack of money is a serious obstacle that could prevent the project from succeeding
obstacle to: sự cản trở đối với
▪ the greatest obstacle to economic progress has been mass unemployment.
overcome an obstacledeal with it successfully
▪ she had to overcome a lot of obstacles to finally make it to drama college.

children.name: bar c2
children.definition: a bar to something/ə ˈbɑːʳ tə something/  something that prevents someone from achieving what they want:là một chướng ngại với cái gì
examples: ▪ his disability was no bar to his entry into the profession.
▪ differences in religious beliefs are not necessarily a bar to a good relationship.

children.name: limiting x
children.definition: limiting/ˈlɪmɪtɪŋ, ˈlɪmətɪŋ/  preventing sth from improving, developing, growing etc: hạn chế, kìm hãm
examples: ▪ i found the lack of available reference books very limiting.
▪ there is a lot of research that still needs to be done, but money is an important limiting factor.

children.name: hamper x
children.definition: hamper/ˈhæmpəʳ/  to make it very difficult for an activity or plan to continue successfully: ngăn trở
examples: ▪ search efforts were hampered by strong winds and fifteen foot waves.
▪ the police’s work is hampered by people who file false complaints.
▪ health care costs are severely hampering the nation’s small businesses.

children.name: hinder c2
children.definition: hinder/ˈhɪndəʳ/  to cause problems and therefore delay the development or progress of something: cản trở
examples: ▪ higher interest rates could hinder economic growth.
▪ society’s attitudes about women hinder any real progress toward equality.
▪ heavy rains had hindered the expedition’s progress through the north-west of the country.

children.name: impede x
children.definition: impede/ɪmˈpiːd/  to make progress or the development of something slower or more difficult: cản trở
examples: progress has been impeded by a number of economic factors.
in fact, the use of these drugs may even impede the patient’s recovery.
storms at seaimpededourprogress.

children.name: prevent b1
children.definition: prevent/stop b1 to make sure that something will not happen or cannot happen, especially something bad.preventis more formal thanstop: ngừng lại, ngăn cản, phòng ngừa
examples: ▪ many people now believe that a good diet can help to prevent cancer.
▪ the new laws are designed to stop discrimination in the workplace.
prevent/stop something (from) happening
▪ a special valve prevents the waste gases from escaping
.▪ stretch the rope out to stop it getting twisted and tangled up.
prevention[u] b2 when something bad is stopped from happening
prevention of
how does a healthy diet help in the prevention of heart attacks?
educating new drivers is important for theprevention of accidents.
crime/accident/fire etc prevention
effective crime prevention must be our main goal.
a fire prevention officer
the police are very happy to talk to local groups about crime prevention.
you know what they say,prevention is better than cure(= it is better to stop something bad from happening than to remove the problem once it has happened ).

children.name: avoid b2
children.definition: avoid/əˈvɔɪd/  to do something to prevent something bad that may happen: tránh
examples: ▪ the company is anxious to avoid an expensive court case.
▪ we take every precaution to avoid accidents.
avoid something at all costsdo everything possible to avoid something happening
▪ civilian casualties must be avoided at all costs.

children.name: avert x
children.definition: avert /əˈvɜːʳt/  formal to do something toprevent something bad that will happen very soon if you do not do anything: ngăn ngừa, ngăn chặn, đẩy lui
examples: ▪ it may already be too late to avert another disaster
.▪ talks will be held today in a final attempt to avert strike action.

children.name: head off x
children.definition: head off to do something to stop a difficult or unpleasant situation from developing, when it seems very likely to happen soon: ngăn chặn, ngừng lại
examples: ▪ they agreed to meet government ministers in an attempt to head off a major conflict
▪ we managed to head off a financial crisis last year, but we may not be so lucky this year.

children.name: guard against x
children.definition: guard against/ˈgɑːʳd əˌgenst/  to carefully plan and think about what you can do in order to prevent something bad from happening: ngăn ngừa cái gì một cách cẩn thận
examples: ▪ the city council is taking emergency measures to guard against flooding in the city centre.
▪ use sunscreen on your skin to help guard against skin cancer.

children.name: to prevent sb from going swh
be in the way u
children.definition: be in the way if someone or something is in the way, they are in a position that stops you from going where you want: cản đường
examples: ▪ there’s a car in the way and i can’t get out of the garage.
be in sb’s way
▪ could you move please sonia. you’re in my way.

children.name: block b2
children.definition: block/blɒkǁblɑːk/  if objects or people block a road, entrance etc, they lie or stand right across it, so that no-one can pass through: làm trở ngại, phong tỏa
examples: ▪ a big truck had turned over on its side, and it was blocking the road.
▪ hundreds of protesters blocked the entrance to the president’s palace.

children.name: obstruct x
children.definition: obstruct/əbˈstrʌkt/  to block or almost block a road, entrance etc: làm tắc nghẽn
examples: ▪ a small aircraft now obstructed the runway.
▪ the driveway was obstructed by piles of stones and gravel.
obstruction[countable noun] sự tắc nghẽn
▪ a truck was causing an obstruction on the road.
▪ construction workers building the tunnel have encountered a number of obstructions.

children.name: blockade x
children.definition: blockade to use military force to prevent people or goods from entering or leaving an area: phong tỏa, bao vây
examples: ▪ in june 1948 the russians blockaded the western sectors of berlin.
▪ a us fleet blockaded the port of veracruz.
blockade[countable noun] sự phong tỏa, bao vây
▪ getting food supplies through the blockade is almost impossible.

children.name: to prevent a plan or action from succeeding
block
children.definition: /blɒkǁblɑːk/  to use something such as a law or an official order to prevent someone from doing something that they have been planning to do:phong tỏa
examples: ▪ britain has threatened to block new eu legislation on human rights.
▪ the deal was blocked by the chairman, who was unwilling to commit so much company money to a risky investment.

children.name: obstruct
children.definition: /əbˈstrʌkt/  to try to prevent someone from doing something by deliberately making it much more difficult for them:làm tắc nghẽn, cản trở
examples: ▪ the house of lords has been accused of obstructing change and preventing scientific progress.
▪ it is an offence to obstruct the police during the course of their duty.
obstruction/əbˈstrʌkʃən/ [countable/uncountable noun]sự tắc nghẽn, cản trợ
▪ the counting of votes was delayed in some areas because of obstruction by local officials.
obstruct of: cản trở cái gì
▪ he was arrested and charged with the obstruction of a police officer.

children.name: thwart
children.definition: /θwɔːʳt/  formal to prevent someone from doing something, especially something that they very much want to do because it is personally important to them:ngăn cản
examples: ▪ harry knew now that nothing could thwart his plans.
▪ an attempt to smuggle heroin worth £30 million into the country has been thwarted by customs officials.

children.name: foil
children.definition: /fɔɪl/  to prevent something bad or criminal that someone is planning to do, by being more clever than they are:ngăn cản, chặn đứng
examples: ▪ the government has foiled an attempted military coup.
▪ the burglar was foiled by a passer-by who noticed the broken window and phoned the police.

children.name: intended to prevent sth from happening
preventive c2
children.definition: preventive/preventative /prɪˈventɪv, prɪˈventətɪv/  intended to prevent something from happening or getting worse:ngăn ngừa, phòng ngừa
examples: ▪ we should spend more money educating people about preventive medicine.
▪ schools must take preventative measures so that this type of tragedy never happens again
.▪ preventative action can easily be taken to avoid damp occurring in your house.

children.name: pre-emptive x
children.definition: pre-emptive/priˈemptɪv/ pre-emptive strike/action/attackan action that is done to harm someone before they can harm you - use this especially about official or military actions: để ngăn ngừa
examples: ▪ the us says it is prepared to launch a pre-emptive strike with nuclear weapons if it is threatened.

children.name: preventable x
children.definition: preventable/prɪˈventəbəl/  something bad that ispreventable, can be prevented:có thể ngăn ngừa
examples: ▪ whooping cough and measles are both preventable diseases
.▪ many of these deaths each year are preventable.

children.name: avoidable x
children.definition: avoidable/əˈvɔɪdəbəl/  difficulties or problems that areavoidablecan be prevented, and therefore you should not have to deal with them:có thể tránh khỏi
examples: ▪ running out of gas is annoying and easily avoidable.
▪ too many children are still injured in avoidable accidents.

children.name: to stop yourself from having or showing a feeling
stifle x
children.definition: stifle/ˈstaɪfəl/  dập tắt
examples: stifle a yawn/a smile/laughter etc
to try to stop yourself showing that you are tired, amused etc especially because you do not want to seem rude:
▪ she stifled a yawn as the boss read out the sales figures.
▪ maria looked away and stifled a giggle.

children.name: hold back c2
children.definition: hold back/ˌhəʊld ˈbæk/  to try hard to stop yourself laughing, crying, or showing anger:kìm nén
examples: hold back something: kìm nén cái gì
▪ jack held back his tears and pretended not to be disappointed
.▪ sarah held back a sob of relief.
hold something back: kìm nén cái gì
▪ i wanted to laugh, but i managed to hold it back.
▪ she struggled to hold her feelings back.

children.name: suppress c2
children.definition: suppress/səˈpres/  written to make a strong effort to stop yourself from showing feelings of anger, sadness etc: kìm nén
examples: ▪ i suppressed an urge to laugh.
▪ he looked at me, waiting with suppressed anger.
▪ it’s not good to suppress your feelings.

children.name: overcome b2
children.definition: overcome/conquer to manage to stop feeling sth that affects you very strongly, for example fear, pain etc:
examples: she managed to overcome her shyness, and stepped forward to introduce herself.
hilton stepped into the room, fighting to conquer his feelings of disgust.

children.name: hold at bay c2
children.definition: hold/keepsth/sbat bay
examples: to prevent someone or something unpleasant from harming you
_exercise can help keep fat at bay.

children.name: defy belief c2
children.definition: defy belief/description/explanation
examples: to be extreme or very strange and therefore impossible to believe, describe or explain

children.name: crackdown c2
children.definition: crackdownnoun
examples: when someone starts to deal with bad or illegal behaviour in a more severe way
_there has been a series of government crackdownsonsafety in factories.

children.name: barrier b2
children.definition: barriernounpreventingrào cản; vật cản trở; chướng ngại vật
examples: anything that prevents people from being together or understanding each other
_despite thelanguagebarrier (= not speaking the same language) , they soon became good friends.
_shyness is one of the biggest barrierstomakingfriends (= something that makes this difficult) .

children.name: keep in b1
children.definition: keepsbinphrasal verb
examples: to make a child stay inside as a punishment, or to make someone stay in hospital
_they kept her in overnight for observation.

children.name: keep off b1
children.definition: keep(sb/sth)offsthphrasal verb
examples: to not go onto an area, or to stop someone or something going onto an area
_there was a notice saying 'keep off the grass'.

children.name: keep away b2
children.definition: keep(sb/sth)awayphrasal verb
examples: to not go somewhere or near something, or to prevent someone from going somewhereor near something
_keep away from the edge of the cliff.

children.name: keep back b2
children.definition: keep(sth/sb)backphrasal verb
examples: to not go near something, or to prevent someone or something from going past a particular place
_barriers were built to keep back the flood water.

children.name: keep off b2
children.definition: keepsthoff(sb/sth)phrasal verb
examples: to stop something touching or harming someone or something
_put a cloth over the salad to keep the flies off.
_wear a hat to keep the sun off (= to prevent it harming your skin) .

children.name: keep sth from sb c2
children.definition: keepsthfromsbphrasal verb
examples: to not tell someone about something
_he says it's alright but i think he's keeping something from me.
